3BNaGEcAdNw1z3udSTH1Bg.text: I just love the rich flavor of the food here!! I got the Rosemary Braised Beef, which was just so delicious and filling. I would totally get it again, and all the other options on the menu seem so yummy as well! There was a period of waiting outside and inside as well, since the seating area isn't particularly large and part of the inside area is also a waiting area. Nonetheless, the wait was bearable and it didn't take too long. I would say it was definitely worth the wait, and I would be happy to come here again to try another one of their menu items!!

photos.caption: Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Rosemary Braised Beef

R_QEeyfV40bOcSK0qbiG7Q.text: Absolutely fantastic food. One of the only few restaurants that leaves me speechless during every bite. The workers there are very friendly and are more than happy to explain the large menu and offer you recommendations.   On the rare occasion when they're not as busy, you'll receive a more standard waiter-style service. Our host seated us at our booth after order, checked up on us from time to time, and refilled our waters. However, expect to fill up your own water and retrieve your own plates and utensils during peak times.  My go-to's are always the baked empanadas, a pollo sandwich, and the alfajores for dessert. The empanadas are freshly made, amazing, and have a different filling each day. They feature three main fillings - a veggie, beef, and chicken (sometimes pork) option. The fillings are intricately crafted and the flavors mesh incredibly well. Pair these with any of their god-tier signature sauces and you'll be swimming through a sea of flavors. Get these for sure.   The Pollo sandwich is large yet inexpensive, and full of flavor, just like everything else on the menu. The grilled ciabatta bread is crispy and robust, the perfect bread to almost contain the overflowing scrumptious contents of this hefty sandwich - caramelized onions, mashed rosemary potatoes, grilled mushrooms, and the thick cut of chicken breast. The chicken itself is marinated in their legendary Ajo garlic sauce (my personal favorite). Cut the sandwich in half, scoop on some sauces before each bite, and you'll wish the sandwich never ends.   Their steaks and steak sandwiches are out of this world as well. Generally cooked to a medium with an amazing wood fire chear and sear, topped with their chimmi sauce. Hands down the best steak I've ever had.   Lastly, the Alfajores....on their website they have kind of a stale description (flavored shortbread with dulce de leche & toasted coconut) but the Alfajores are so much more than that. The shortbread on these cookies are unlike anything I've ever had before. The Alfajores are a tiny cookie sandwich rimmed with the toasted coconut. The cookie is unbelievably soft and the dulce de leche is the perfect choice to hold these two soft pillowy shortbread cookies together. Each bite is an otherworldly experience.   The sauces are essential with every meal at Gaucho and can be paired with whatever is in front of you (except maybe the Alfajores - I'll try that next time). So, I will attempt to do my best to describe the four... Ajo - My favorite sauce, pairs well with everything on the menu. Has a robust garlicy and rosemary flavor. Scoop this on everything.  Chimmi - Fantastic on steaks and the chicken, a bit more watery than the other 3 heavenly sauces but the herbs and flavors of this one keeps me coming back.  Pimenton - Has a slight vinegary tang, but the strong fire roasted pepper comes through in this one, with a hint of freshly ground black peppercorn. Great on any of the empanadas Cebolla - Amazing balance of flavors featuring caramelized onions that have been slow roasted and melded into this amazing concoction. Great on everything as well.    I'd be more than happy waiting 2 hours in line to just grab a single empanada from Gaucho. This place deserves nothing less than 5 stars, and it shows in their quality, preparation, and flavors of their food.

Ngk_WE6Sry85Oyf7PSNd8Q.text: This is probably my favorite restaurant in Pittsburgh. The meat is phenomenal and the sauces are a MUST. The menu has staples but the sides and small plates are always changing which is nice to spice things up.

pYUq8CfcDkvO-shgxMcEJg.text: My friend Rachel C brought me to Gaucho on my recent Pittsburgh trip and it was a total riot. The guys who work there are hilarious and super flirty - hanging out while we waited for our food was so much fun!  We both opted for steak sandwiches with chimichurri and caramelized onions. The sandwich was delicious and very filling. We also ordered sides of the roasted potatoes and vegetables, which were great.   We managed to hit Gaucho on the final day before they closed for renovations. Wishing them the best and looking forward to checking out the updates next time I'm in Pittsburgh!

aYIsqm1p2VLXCwDRqqkR6g.text: Simply the best food in Pittsburgh. The food is all super fresh, the sauces are amazing!

SJTGZ48eCStoxxWN7j4LHg.text: Kind of disappointed at this place. Came herefor my birthday and I felt like there wasn't a lot of flavor / spices in any of the dishes except the empanadas and steak was great. On the other hand the sauce area just looked like a mess- flies were surrounded it and it just looked unappealing to try.

vFqlPbcHKFTN23eRfGkzAg.text: Growing up in PR, we didn't have fancy Brazilian Steak Houses, we had fancy Argentinian Parrilladas. When we were exploring places to visit in our visit to Pittsburgh, this place popped towards the top of the places to visit, and when my friend mentioned it, I couldn't be more excited!  This Parilla is a casual place where you place your order at the counter and then are seated. The food is delivered to your table. They have sodas and water but not beer or wine. They do have a byob policy.  The menu consists mainly of Argentinian specialties, and, of course, the ultimate Argentinian specialty, beef.  Since there were 5 of us at the table, we ordered a sample plate with an additional flank steak. We also ordered the grilled corn, Gaucho Papas, and humitas (a savory corn pudding). We also got the empanadas, and chicken wings as starters and the grilled pineapple, and alfajores for dessert.  There was a selection of different sauces to pick from, from the traditional chimichurri to a slightly spicy pepper one.  The chicken wings and beef empanadas were ok, not really that great. The beef needed seasoning and the wings were a little dry. Using the sauces provided helped a lot with these items. The same with the humitas.  The alfajores were a bit dry, the cookie was crumbly and dry and took away from the delicious filling.  But everything else was really good! The steaks were delicious and flavorful and the sauces complimented them to perfection. The grilled corn was really tasty, although I would have preferred a bit more salt, and the grilled pineapple is probably the best application of this idea I've ever had, so damned good!  All in all the meal was a hit, with not one dish that I would consider bad, and many items that I would happily eat all the time.  For the price, this place definitely deserves the 5 stars!

QoUpDDOt8rOy4e9uzJU1dQ.text: The line does tend to wrap around the block (we saw it earlier in the evening). Tip- go later and go when it is raining. We experienced no wait under these circumstances. After our order, we waited very little time for our food to arrive at our table. The place is casual and you immediately feel comfortable. We got the fungos (Cremona mushrooms, shallots, sherry vinegar, rosemary), cammarones (grilled rosemary, garlic shrimp w/ lemon), pescado ( fish of the day), and asado platter- all 5 cuts of wood fired steak. This was the best meal of my Pittsburgh trip and I will be craving it a lifetime. No other shrimp will ever compare. The meat, oh the meat... All five cuts were perfectly medium rare. One tasted better than the other so I kept going back and forth. Loved the mushrooms. The fish was good but everything else overshadowed it. I ate until I was in pain. Service was friendly. We brought a bottle of wine to accompany our meal. The overprice for the quality resulted in a high value meal.  I can't wait to return here.

XWnYzcbrI7ZRdqnxRkhqCA.text: As a vegetarian, I was hesitant to come here. To my surprise they had a few options! I got the veg sandwich and it was so good! My other non-veg friends got steak, and said it was delicious.

DMcXEsVbNaEC6Jli6vFnhw.text: If your in the strip district, you need to go to this restaurant. It's an experience. You will wait but it's worth every minute. It's a BYOB and make sure you are hungry. We ordered the empanadas for the table as appetizers with some chorizo too. Perfect starters. Then we ordered the strip and omg is the only way to describe it. The chicken is delicious too. Sides of potatoes and root vegetables made a perfect combination.   I will miss this place when my daughter graduates. Might have to make a special trip.

Sv2Km7Yf7DCtuejiT282qQ.text: BottomLine: Destination: yup! Faves: wing, pork, shrimp  In a bizarre way, their pork is my fave pulled pork in PGH. It's wonderfully smoked, and you can accoutre it w chimi or garlic or onion sauce, but it's awesome on its own, w the crusty bread that comes with.  Backing up, we started w the wings. Just say, "Yes." This could be an entree. Big, meaty w a wonderful smoke.  K had the shrimp, and it was fantastically grilled and  flavorful enough so they definitely made it theirs, but not too much to step on the subtleties of the beast.  Evil dark chocolate dessert. If you can't make din din for some silly reason, get the deep dark chocolate loveliness.  Table full of regular guys had sammies, and they looked all that, even if you just see the bread.  Ambiance is plain, functional but the chunky wooden tables and seats appeal to me. Staff is knowledgeable and very pleasant; those who are fans of fashionable female form may get more from their visit.  I believe this is still a BYO.

gTtT317j1qow-aspCS5buw.text: This place used to be great but as they've grown in popularity and in physical space, it's really gone down the tubes. The food is still good, but they've developed the snobby hipster attitude you'd expect in San Francisco. We arrived at 8:43 pm on a Saturday, on which they closed at 10 pm. We were told they weren't accepting anymore customers but managed to finagle our way into seat at a high top in the hallway. We asked for the menu and were told "we don't have menus, you need to look it up online". We proceeded to try and read the lo-res photo of a chalkboard menu. Neither of us could actually read any of the descriptions so just crossed our fingers and hoped we would like our order. The experience was downhill from there...   The food was fine but everyone from the cashier to the 2 different waiters we interacted with were down right rude. We will NEVER come back to Gaucho. I won't recommend readers of this post do anything on account of our experience, but I tried to warn you!!

stIGUNFMMg_GDk4BIZFtrw.text: This review is fairly late (short & sweet) but I have yet to forget about how amazing the food was @ Gaucho's.  This is the sandwich by which all other sandwiches must be judged.  If you were allowed to give only one five star review per Yelp account, this would be my ultimate end-all be-all five star.  Amazing.  I am forever spoiled.    Hopefully these incredible chefs gather a solid following and branch out to other cities and venues.  Holy foodgasm. This is what Pittsburgh should be known for. 10/10 awesomesauce.  Can't wait to go back.  A+++++

2-9tEDk9BNYRdxbJCIpIog.text: I've lived in Argentina, Netherlands and Argentine Queens (NYC). NOTHING comes close to the authenticity, especially in Pittsburgh.

w-U-fr2hOctQ0p-ypjLo4A.text: Stopped by after picking up kid from Pitt. Came on a weekday. Grab your condiments, cutlery and stuff prior to selecting your food. I loved my lamb chops. This is an Argentinian restaurant,  so it came out braying. Lol. Great food will stop again!

elZN6mujHOOZNmjNJCJCRQ.text: fantastico....great food and great service at very reasonable prices.  Had empanadas, Arrechera steak, baked yam with marshmallows and honey, saffron rice....wish I had known that this is a BYOB place.

gyw0lPTpJOqVpNbxp0c10Q.text: Gaucho, a vegan's paradise! Just kidding.  If you're not craving a lump of meat that's been resting on a hot grill for several minutes, then you should probably head on over to your local farmer's market or graze the grass in your neighbor's backyard.  But if you find happiness in ripping apart dead animal flesh with a fork and knife, dipping it into variety of native south american dipping sauces (4 flavors to choose from), and sloppily mashing it in between your teeth while beads of sweat drip off your face into the puddle beneath you, then wait no longer!  Request that uber, jack a few bottles from your roommate's prized craft beer collection, and call up that cool chick who's down to guzzle some brews, munch on medium rare cow, and crack a few dick jokes!  Now that we've filtered out the gentle, ethical souls from the carnivorous, protein fueled, ruthless beasts, let's get to the nitty gritty with how gaucho works.  If you venture down to the strip district on 16th and Penn on a Friday or Saturday night, you'll be waiting outside the door for 30-45 minutes.  The crowd you'll be cuddling with for warmth if you make the trip between November and March will be in the age range of 25-50 and will be wearing an assortment of high end peacoats and Nordstrom-bought dresses and high heels.  Once inside, you make a quick scan of the menu which includes the Vaca section - what cut from the dead cow you look to ingest, sandwich section - what type of dead animal you'd like to be placed on your french bagguete, or the salad section - I'm not sure what this entails but I'm guessing there will be greens, cheese, fruit, and oils all mixed together - as salad is an after-thought at this Argentinian meat house.  You order at the counter, wait to get seated, sit, eat, guzzle your drinks (byob) and leave.  It's loud, crowded, and everyone's drunk, but the food is still the focal point here.  Nobody can ignore the high quality meat and flavor which actually comes at a fair price (6 oz sirloin for 12 bucks).  The waitstaff was friendly and they all seem like cool people. 8/10 - would go back.

fDdnL7D5pt5OoCMRLJ2TRg.text: Delicious! Neat little place - service with a twist. The menu is so big and on a huge chalkboard - plan ahead so you're not overwhelmed. We had the braised Rosemary roast beef sandwich and the fish of the day. The sandwich was amaze balls. The sauces (red pepper and onion) were great too. We will be back very soon to try more items! No issue with the line or seating!

75z-cJh5Wa-yM_E67URIuw.text: Oh my goodness. If you love meat, this place is your Nirvana. Stopped in for a quick lunch while I was downtown. I'm from out of town and had no clue where I was. Yelp hooked me up though! This place is so good!   I had the rosemary beef sandwich with horseradish and a side salad. The side salad was mixed greens with roasted tomatoes and caramelized onions on it. $5 seemed a little steep for the small salad, but it was tasty, so I'm good with it.   The sandwich was about the size of my head... and I have a large head. Seriously, if you can finish this sandwich in one sitting, congrats. Tons of beef and caramelized onions and horseradish. Simple and delicious.   The best part is that you can try their homemade sauces and the chimichurri sauce is mind-boggling. Garlic, cilantro, tons of herbs, vinegar... and some other stuff. I took a take-home cup of it because I want it to be on everything I eat for the next few days. Seriously, super duper delicious.   This place is for real. Don't get scared off by the "$$". If you just go get a giant sandwich for $10, you are definitely getting your money's worth.   For what it's worth, they also had some tasty-looking veggie sandwich options too.   Check this place out.

61V-2O_hlQsO1wYZ5PNrwg.text: I eat here fairly often.  Always excellent.  Its tough to consistently get meats cooked properly to temperature -- Gaucho never misses the mark.  All of the sauces, especially the chimichurri and the smoked red pepper sauce, are excellent.  Service is good -- not Michelin 3-star dining, but prompt and quick.  No complaints.  Want a good piece of meat, grilled right, with some excellent grilled veggies?  This is the place.

hrq94iC_By-bMtEjUeJ_kg.text: I've been eyeing this place for a while, by which I mean smelling it.   You can smell the smoke rolling off of a place such as this from blocks away. It's the same reason why you never see an ad for Cinnabon. If you get people by the nose, their ass will follow promptly.   I was pleased upon entering to see a clean, and well decorated place. I dread walking into a new place, and seeing that perhaps someone can cook, but be clueless as to how to make a guest feel welcome. The sun was bursting through the windows onto saffron-colored walls and butcher block counters. A giant rosemary plant sat in the window. Every detail was in place.   Prices for sandwiches looked little steep, but what landed in front of me was the size of my 4th grade lunchbox, so no worries there. I was still in a daze looking at the sandwich on a giant piece of ciabatta bread, when our host was directing us to choose from sauces on the center table to garnish our lunch. Ajo, Pimenton, Cebolla and Chimi Churri, or to you, Anglo, este es roasted garlic, roasted red pepper, roasted sweet onion, and the tradtional sauce of many South American barbecue styles. What Chimi Churri means depends greatly on where you happen to be standing. Some places use a bit of oregano, others some cilantro. All of them center on fresh parsley, olive oil, a bit of garlic and red wine vinegar. These all sat in tasteful jars with sample cups to portion out. It was hard to not get carried away, to be candid.  My sandwich was big enough I chose to cut it in half, and try the pimenton on one half, the ajo on the other. The ajo is thoroughly grilled, so the flavor almost has a savory nuttiness to it, instead of the pungent sulphur blast that we often associate with garlic. The pimenton was even better, grilling having mellowed the sweetness of the red pepper, balanced with a pleasing combo of herbs, oil, and vinegar.   Let's get something out of the way here, Pittsburgh. Corn on the cob is not to be boiled. As they do south of the border, and also at Gaucho, the ears are placed directly on the grill. Soaked in water first, and grilled with the husk still on, it arrived in a bit of tinfoil, the husk charred black. Peeled back, and used as a handle, there is no need for the Midwestern American plastic corn cob holders. Throw those ridiculous things in the recycle bin, please. Corn originates from Meso-America. Trust me, our neighbors to the south know exactly what they're doing. The husk protects the corn from scorching, and it steams in it's own skin, acquiring that important smoky flavor. The carmelized flavors of the cebolla sauce were a perfect compliment.  I am almost afraid to tout this place so highly, in that it may become too busy to get some of the awesome grub they're putting out.

l_9qKFmFQuHftFNQD9xfTA.text: Excellent spot in the Strip District! Visited recently when I was in Pittsburgh from out of town. Great menu selection of appetizers, mains [including sandwiches, salads, and steak plates] along with sides and desserts! Was there during the weekday lunch hour, which can get quite busy, so plan your order ahead, or come during off peak times if your schedule is tight. The great 90's playlist just adds to the whole experience!

ZqI0QDC2yLEea4hA1DvJGg.text: After reading all the reviews I can say that the hype about Gaucho is True!  The meat is absolutely fantastic.  My husband and I split a skirt steak.  The only thing is a bit weird is how you order at a counter and sit down for your meal.  It is quite pricey for this kind of set up, however given the quality of the food I can let this little detail aside.  Make sure you try all of their sauces- absolutely fantastic!  I can't wait to come back and try other things.

NBEG3tiCF2QUhCJTrQcHww.text: Best steak sandwich I've ever had. You can see them grilling the steak as you order, so fresh and delicious.   I got the rib eye steak sandwich and it had 5-6 large pieces of steak on a large cibatta (don't quote me on the cibatta bun, it could have been something else), with caramelized onions and roasted red peppers. Mmm, salivating just thinking about it.   The server came outside to their patio seating and asked me how the sandwich was. Nice touch!   Not much seating inside, but nice patio seating.   Very pleased and a must-try when you are in the Pittsburgh area.

m8gEX8Q4mhg_-RbBWhe4TQ.text: One of my favorite places to eat. Especially if you like beef.

pmTpXhh2XyGOw6O2Av-uYQ.text: If I could, I would live on a cross-beam of the 16th Street Bridge, so I could eat here 10 times a week.  Great food, reasonably priced.  Friendly staff.  Parking can be a pain, I suspect.  But my party got there early--about 11:30 AM and we missed the noon rush.  I had one of the steak sandwiches; my pal had the pork.  We also got a sample of the empanadas.  We were very happy people.   We did not want to leave.  Ever.   My pal called today...he went there without me and had the wings.  He says they were fantastic.  He now joins me in looking for a cross-beam to declare residence near the restaurant.

YOmQ1Jd8sR1X7P6UIPrT8w.text: Unpopular opinion of the century alert: I know this place is talked up quite a lot and voted on all sorts of lists, but I just do not get it. I've been here two or three times and have been disappointed. The meat is always charred and I can not tolerate what I feel is purposely burnt food. It makes me gag. Blegh. I've had good vegetables here, but um, I can make those at home no problem. A lot of their menu is in Spanish, at least the section titles, which I get and is cute but it confuses a lot of English speaking folks and makes the line move that much slower because YES, there will be a line. Nothing wrong with English in parentheses! Last time I was here I did enjoy their chicken sandwich, but would not make it a point to come back for another. Their sauces are good as well, I will give them that.

xi86Tx-IlZzCi6h-slUwYQ.text: Gaucho is THE place to go when you have friends in town. It's a bit salty and greasy, but still, who can resist Gaucho

ueKFXTCcvRJc2PfVFun-sQ.text: Gaucho Parilla. Considering this is a hotspot, this place is great. However, the meat is a bit on the rarer side on the inside and charred on the outside. However, the sauces they have (chimichurri, ajo, etc.) are amazing! You must flavor your meat like this! It is a very hip experience, and is an awesome place to eat lunch! However, make sure to be prepared for a line and/or come early. The menu is also kind of narrow. In conclusion, I give this restaurant four stars because it is a great atmosphere, but the meat isn't as amazing as authentic Argentinian meat, which I have tried before. This might be because it is the US and it would be too hard to import (duh). But, yeah, I definitely recommend this place...

cxbG7QX3Ce57yJ4nCKh82Q.text: Awesome carnivore BYOB paradise.  Steak, braised beef, chorizo, yams and bread pudding to die (and wait in line) for.  A real gem.  Been there twice in past two months and can't wait to go back.

_UygLef22a5uFhgSQEyMDQ.text: This place is off-the-charts great! Don't let the long line keep you from going - it moves fast. The food is fantastic, staff is friendly, and the atmosphere is cozy. I cannot wait to go back.

8FQZHrKLR1dSdW8elQRxxg.text: Simply the best steak sandwich in pittsburgh! The meat is amazing and the staff friendly and helpful. The gentleman working the counter even offered to come around to explain all the chef's homemade sauces to us. I will be back again and again!

f2g9_1pijFah92Axs5JX5Q.text: Wonderful food served by very nice guys who obviously love what they are doing.  We went to Gaucho during a weekend visit to Pittsburgh. We wanted to eat at a local place and were interested in meat - we are low-carbers so we are always hunting (no pun intended) for good meat places. Gaucho was the first 5 stars place that Yelp brought up when I put "steak" and it seemed like a non-brainer, so we went there and were able to find parking on the street pretty much in front of the restaurant.  The place is tiny and pretty simple and nice inside - just my kind of rustic decor. They also have a small patio outside, but being sort of a balmy day, we decided to stay inside. My husband and I shared the asado plate and our son ate the steak sandwich. Everything was delicious. We know really good meat and the one from our asado plate was beyond awesome. They don't have "real" silverware and I was thinking about how we could eat steak with plasticware. Well, the asado comes pre-sliced, almost bite-sized, so really what you need is your fork. The meat is so tender that you don't even need a good set of teeth - it is really that soft. Their chimichurri was delicious too (it was served as a garnish on top of the meat). Not too garlicky, which I really appreciate, and they put just the right amount of it. I really have a big problem when they put so much of the garnish on the meat that all you can taste is the garnish. Not here - it was really perfect. The same goes for the amount of dressing in the side salad I had. It wasn't drenched in balsamic dressing, which I loved. The greens were fresh and crunchy, and there was just the perfect touch of dressing. And oh, the meat comes with two wonderfully charred/browned buttered pieces of toasted ciabatta. I don't eat gluten but it was so beautiful that I had to take a bite, and it was worthy of the stomach pain I felt afterwards (damn gluten!).  Our son's sandwich was also beautiful and HUGE. It was inside a toasted ciabatta roll and, according to him, it was AWESOME (and if you read any of my other reviews, "awesome" is the highest compliment a food can receive).   An observation: They were out of a lot of stuff, including cheese, which sounded so incredibly odd to me, as cheese is one of those things that don't spoil too easily so kind of weird that they run out of it. They were also out of empanadas, melon and prosciutto, ribs, and a bunch of other things. The only reasonable explanation I could find is that probably they don't have a lot of fridge space and try to always have fresh ingredients, so since we went on a Saturday, mid-afternoon, and they are closed on Sunday and Monday, we probably caught them at the end of their stock. Nevertheless, looks like they can use a good supply chain manager so their inventory management is a better. If I lived in Pittsburg I'd volunteer and would gladly receive my salary in steak and salad! :-)

WcmE6FryZaEyZ1Knycz61w.text: Overpriced and overhyped. The ordering process is terrible. Stand in line for an hour to order then hope there's a table ready between then and when your food comes out. Steak sandwich was good. Shrimp were overlooked and overpriced. $18 for 12, they should be large and delicious, they weren't. Salads had around 6 pieces of lettuce with 50 cent sides. Spent $45 for dinner for two with no sides or drinks and had to go to primantis after to fill up. If you must go because you've heard so much hype like ourselves, stick to the sammiches.

ej2eKnjzGYQEGu9RQ26yTg.text: Where to start...the empanadas, the braised beef sandwich, flank steak, or the grilled shrimp. It's all amazing. When in the strip if the lines it too long this is the place. Gaucho has this down pat!

9797DdBcdLcGolC3LaJy9g.text: Truly an amazing restaurant. Went because of Yelp reviews and I was not disappointed. Wings and lamb were phenomenal. Food on the menu all showed an adherence to quality. Staff can come off a bit rude at first but the service is fantastic. Looks like they also serve corn on the Cobb but it's not on the menus so ask for it! Can't wait to go back.

mXXDLA8YTaMG_lTCkUv9ag.text: I like the wings a lot, perhaps the best wings in the city.  I've also heard amazing things about the burger, but you can't really go wrong.

yBDf5on5tDZtoLoe6O84Fg.text: Absolutely fantastic and satisfying food. Options for vegetarians as well as all the carnivorous delights. The seating situation is a bit frustrating but it's a popular restaurant for a reason and to be expected.

UTG9rViLYoCQKbdpeOlErA.text: Very busy every time I go but it is worth the wait. Great food and priced reasonably .  Chorizo sausage is the best and they let you bring your own wine with no corkage fee

0a_zJ8ImU4mZfMxNlEQLNA.text: Wow, what can I add that so many of these other reviews haven't already said? Not much. My sons and I each ordered carne sandwiches. They had the flank steak and the filet mignon while I had the NY Strip. They loved theirs. As for me, that might just well have been the best sandwich of any type I've ever had. Just absolute perfection. The bread (perfect in this role - crunch in the crust but soft on the inside and able to soak up all the juices and not fall apart), the roasted, marinated peppers and onions, the fresh chimichurri, and the absolutely incredible meat. So flavorful, so juicy, so full of wood smoke. Perfection. And no need for a knife. Just melts in your mouth. I live in DC and cannot wait to come back. This place does Pittsburgh proud!

O3oH0_BAQCdbdFj50oeRKw.text: This is a hole in the wall in the strip district (the website photos are, shall we say, optimistic). But the food is delicious. So far the best I've had in Pittsburgh (better than Salt, Spoon, Soba, Point Bruge, etc.). High quality meats, good spices, and all really fresh. Probably not something to eat on a low sodium diet but delicious.

71bxpB2MLmq0QeMXmTbGAQ.text: Amazing!!!.. the CARNE anything is the best. I'd rather eat their steak over $50 downtown restaurant steaks any day of the week!

jj6cwi2IUoTGA0lR1b2Y9A.text: This place was amazing. I ordered the steak sandwich and selected the skirt steak. There are many cuts of beef to choose from for this sandwich including flank, skirt, NY strip and filet mignon. I asked the cashier for his recommendation and he suggested the skirt steak so that's what I went with. The sandwich was amazing and the steak very flavorful. I would recommend this place to anyone. My boyfriend got the sandwich with flank steak. It was good but the skirt is the way to go. The added fat in that cut of meat elevates the taste. This is a MUST try in Pittsburgh.

Zd9h3LsIy9dpySQ5LWkD9Q.text: Delicious fresh food at a reasonable price. The pollo was so tender and flavorful. There is limited space, but it's worth the wait.

aW2ZjZHU7J3VbFsIwoQG8Q.text: Most consistent food in Pittsburgh.  Always an amazing experience.  Must stop if you are in the burgh.  The gaucho salad and the mushrooms were a favorite.

-wVOLrL7M-banWWj0A_Rkw.text: Gaucho is beyond awesome. The meat is high-quality product, over-the-top well prepared. The staff is enthusiastic about what they do. The whole experience is like going to a good friend's house, discovering that some of your other friends have also come over, and then being served implausibly good food.

vgSdcQmVZzFlRDXrjVlkHQ.text: I don't always eat meat, but when I do, I prefer Gaucho.    Stay hungry, my friend.

6OAjmYPJvPu9XM54ck2wwQ.text: Awesome place for tasty MEATs! Grilled with real hardwood onsite.  When you see the smoke coming out of the stack you get what you smell.  Very small and intimate only a handful of seats but worth the trouble.  Tastes were heavenly with caramelized onions and fresh crusty breads.  The gentleman at the counter works the room like a carnival barker but takes great care of the orders.  Great prices and fairly good selection of meaty delights.

V01xZhoVuSDPebr3MAmYhg.text: Amazing. First day in Pittsburg, came here with the family for lunch and got the chicken sandwich. Also tried the steak sandwich. We had a side of roasted potatoes and a generous helping of all their sauces. Everything was fresh and delicious. It was our first time in Gaucho and the staff was attentive and really nice. They talked with us and explained the menu really well. Worth every penny. If I lived in Pittsburgh I would definitely come back.

EFr_Y547hpgBwz6ni8muuQ.text: Absolutely amazing and True to the ratings and reviews. Best steak sandwich I've had!! A must try!

1KY7Q4cMvkH0svW1a8W1Pg.text: I came here because of all the good reviews but left the restaurant with disappointment. I ordered sirloin and lamb rack and both were extremely bitter to me because the meat and bread were burnt. The flavor was nothing special, and the sirloin was very chewy. Lamb had good texture, but the bitterness ruined everything. I don't even think it's safe to consume food that is burnt like this?? Anyways, I probably would not come here again. I really don't understand why there are so many good reviews....

photos.caption: Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Sirloin and lamb rack

DQmRj_SES2Ui3-1TROPm1g.text: At last! I made it to Gaucho! I've been waiting to check this place out for years, and I'm so happy that it lived up to the high expectations that I had for it! The space is small, and yes you will be greeted by a line. The line leads you right to the counter where you are given your drinks, your wine is uncorked for you (BYOB) and you are then someone takes your order on an ipad. The line seemed to move very quickly, mostly because I couldn't choose what to order off of the chalkboard (so so many options)   Once we were seated, our food didn't take long to arrive at all. I absolutely loved all of the food that we ordered. We had one main course, which came with a salad, and then we ordered some of the sides and features. Everything was hot! and high quality! There wasn't much service while we were seated, as in, you don't have a specific waiter/waitress they all just help each other out with refills and busing tables.   The employees here were all extremely friendly! which is always a +1 star in my book. I loved that this restaurant is BYOB. I expected the decor to be different, would be nice for them to spruce up the place a bit! Also, i would have loved to have some music playing in the background. We sat on the top floor and it was extremely difficult to have a conversation because it was just so noisy with all of the other tables talking.   Would highly recommend Gaucho! Check the hours first, they are closed on Sunday and Monday. I can't wait to go back!

photos.caption: Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Eggplant feature
Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Ribeye, excellent!
Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

QSVwwCLrDxGNkjCKSaaT4g.text: An incredible restaurant in Pittsburgh. This BYOB, Argentinian restaurant took us way too long to get to, as locals. We got four small plates: the flank steak, the sirloin, the Cerdo (pork with carmelized onion & Dijon) and the Provoletta (grilled provolone cheese). The sirloin and the cerdo were outstanding. The flavor in all of our dishes rendered me speechless. We highly recommend getting a few small plates to try together. The menu is so extensive, you'd be cheating yourself if you didn't. It's pricier but it's worth it. Tip: get there early before 5:15 on a weeknight and avoid the rush. 5/5, we will definitely return.

8R-PiseDMgsIwRYp3eiwqA.text: My friends and I had a great visit to "Gaucho" this past weekend. This is one of the hottest food destinations in the Steel city. It's usually pack, but in this snowy day there was barely a wait.  The wait staff were lovely. Helping the group choose some of their most popular items on the menu. Our group typically buys a bunch of food so that we can each sample, and this place is great for that. Offering small bites that pack a big punch.   The food a great. All the meats were perfectly cooked, tender, and chalked full of flavor. My favorite item from this visit with the flank steak, followed by the beef empanadas.  I also LOVE the pay up front aspect. Takes the complication out of splitting bills at the end of the meal.

photos.caption: Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Sweet Chorizo &amp; Spicy Chorizo
Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Feast
Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

n_YDttCC5YZO_jdj-syjdw.text: My husband and I went there for my birthday and ordered the Asado Platter and six empanadas, the empanadas were too little but everything it was more than enough for the both of us. The chimis are amazing. There is no spicy ones.  We waited a long time in line but they immediately served us our food.  Perfect service from each and everyone of the people who served us.

photos.caption: Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Asado Plate
Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Menu

84SSCwdwSeE2IroQTQGwxQ.text: Everything is wonderful, just be sure to get there early or you will be waiting in line, but even if you do get stuck in line...worth it!

photos.caption: Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. The flank steak was amazing!

uLs3mrGGxoiQpJqrbAXq6A.text: I asked a few locals (cashiers, uber drivers, etc) what their recommendations were since I was visiting Pitt for a weekend conference and every single person recommended Gaucho Parrilla. It was such an easy decision to come here, and I would do it again!!   Came in on a weekday and there was still a line out the door (although waiting area/line is kind of a small space), and the line went by fairly quickly.   I'm sure all their selections are good, but I had to go for the flank steak plate because it was one of the cheapest, but it was still sooooo good. It was well seasoned, not too salty, juicy and so flavorful.  Also ordered all 3 empenadas to share with the group. Great textured breading and flavorful meat/veggies. Great for sharing, and try a little bit of everything.   Great ambiance, service, and food! Highly recommended.

1bWAPTSjHUSSRLOGMFeEQA.text: The food was great here as was the service. The only reason I'm giving this 4 stars is how we were greeted when we first there. We walked in with a group of 5 on a busy night. It was already a lot of people in the restaurant and the line was long. It was so cold so we squeezed into the door and were rudely told to wait outside because there wasn't enough room inside, which we get. However, her delivery could have been better. We hadn't even ordered or sat down to eat and that really just turned us off.  Thankful for the kindness and welcoming smiles from the employees taking orders and the attentiveness and kindness from the wait staff. Also, the food is amazing so that turned our experience around.  We decided to order a bunch of food and do a sort of family style. We decided to do that because there were so many things that we wanted to try. Glad that we did because nothing disappointed us. We got small plates, sides, and a meat plate.   For sides we got papas al horno (roasted red skin potatoes), broccolini, and roasted mixed vegetables. The small plates that we did chor y pan (sweet or spicy sausage), camarones (grilled shrimp), and provoletta (provolone cheese on toast with oregano and salad). Then we did the asado steak platter that came with chimichurri sauce. It was all so amazing

photos.caption: Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

7mujfdBnAvqeZfs7og6bgQ.text: Wow! We weren't so happy to have to wait in the cold in order to get inside, but WOW was this worth the wait. We got the Asado Platter, the Parrillada Mixta (with spicy chorizo), and a small steak plate (because there wasn't already enough meat...), along with the Papas al Horno and Roasted Spaghetti Squash. The food was phenomenal. The meat was perfectly cooked and seasoned, and the sides were a great complement to the meats. And it's BYOB without any fee, so you really can't complain about that!  We had a few dietary restrictions in our group (no gluten, no dairy), but the staff was very knowledgeable and they were able to easily accommodate us.  We will definitely be returning to enjoy more of the delicious food!

photos.caption: Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. A mix of food, including the papas al horno and the roasted spaghetti squash
Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Parrillada Mixta with spice chorizo
Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

KOKr_2M30vAhUmA1DefAgg.text: One of my favorite places. I've never had something I didn't love. My go to is the arrachera. I've waited in line 90 minutes before and still thought it was worth it.   Line tip - try early on a week day. Or call ahead and get take out.

LHNHuut62IeNP6tLd8FyGg.text: Well worth the wait if you have one. I went during lunch and it only took 10 minutes to get seated. Food is awesome. Definitely one of my favorite spots. Had the pulled pork sandwich and veggies. Sandwiches are huge! You don't need a side to fill you up but I would recommend just so you can try more awesomeness. Staff is friendly, prices are on par for what you get.   Do it.

_AlpILWkSn5coCbTgV0VqA.text: Awesome steak.  Worth the wait.  Empenadas and pulled pork were both just okay, but decent enough.  No reservations and order at the counter--ordering was actually a little bit weird and inefficient, but the food more than made up for it.

_8hTt37iVHzKzotM7RJ0HQ.text: Gaucho Parrilla Argentina is a very unique little restaurant with a lot of flavor! I can see why it is so popular, but since I'm vegan and can't partake in the "full" experience which would likely include their meats, I also can't! So take my review with a grain of salt ;) And some of their delicious sauces because that stuff is ADDICTING.   Since I'm on the topic, Gaucho Parilla Argentina has four free flowing sauces available to all patrons. I probably consumed too much of the ajo-garlic one because it was out of this world. It was creamy but not in a weird way and the garlic was subtle and blended so well that I drizzled (ok, drenched) my food in this sauce. I also love the chimi sauce, but I have a feeling it goes together much better with meats than the veggies I ordered.   Speaking of which, I ordered the beans and greens as a side for $4 and the large Argentino Salad for $12. The prices are pretty awesome! My boyfriend ordered meat things, and he seemed to really enjoy them. I absolutely loved the beans and greens because they had an awesome smoky flavor, so I didn't really feel like I was missing out by not partaking in the non-vegan experience.   I think it's totally possible for vegans to get by on the sides and salads here (with the incredible sauces!!!) because they are all so delicious! Just be prepared for a bit of a line and plan accordingly. Also BYOB!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Argentino salad!

tT2G6XjlfZZIqWI2sslamQ.text: Excellent service here, and staffs are all polite and friendly! I really love their beef ( sorry for forgetting the name), and their salads is amazing. You can choose different kinds of sauces there, most of which are Argentina traditional sauces, and the spicy one is my favorite. However, with some unknown reasons, their mussels that day were not very fresh, although they guaranteed that mussels are received on that day. Also, the salmon and bread were overcooked that day. We could not have another piece of salmon cuz that was the last one on that day. The food wasn't give me a good reflection, but the manager there was very polite and gave us another bread with some desserts for our lost.  Anyway, it's a good restaurant with different and amazing atmosphere, maybe we will come back later.

86-DcnY0Q1wewpbqifm-Kg.text: Probably one of my favorite establishments in my very brief adventures in Pittsburgh. I got there after work and was greeted by a line that circled the shop onto Penn Ave. This was probably the most unfun part since it was starting to get cold and I forgot my thicker jacket. Several patrons had the right ideas of bringing some beers to enjoy, which was the better idea it took almost 30 mins to get inside. Side note: BYOB and no corkage fee.  I ordered the carne con pan, which is basically a steak sandwich with roasted bell peppers, caramelized onions, and chimicurri inside. I chose the ribeye, cooked medium rare (of course), and I was not disappointed. These folks know how it cook it right. HOWEVER, skip the roasted bell peppers as they overpower the meat. The extra sauces/salsas on the side it made it that much better. And if they have it, grab a side of the marinated eggplant - straight fire . Good stuff, I'll be back again soon when the line is shorter.

photos.caption: Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

YYUFK4k3ISDeiprEt69pxA.text: Went on a Saturday at 1 pm. We thought it would be slow but we were wrong. The line went out the door and seating/ orders had been stopped until space cleared up. Once we got our food (30 mins later), it was easy to see what all the fuss was about. We ordered the ASADO PLATTER. Wow. Now I'm a steak lover but I don't think I'd had an abundance of different, and delicious, types of meat at once like I did that day. My favorite were: the skirt and flank steak, the NY strip was close second; but they were all succulent and mouth watering. Also ordered the CHORYPAN, which had a kick to it but was still very savory and complimented well by the onions. CREMINI SHROOMS were well made and did not have the mushy texture that mushrooms sometimes get, but they weren't dry either. QUIQUI CHICKY was also very well seasoned and properly cooked. The chimichurri sauce that the chicken came in was the perfect touch. Having chimichurri sauce easily available for the other meats was a plus! VEGETARIAN: the place is primarily meat based but there are some options you can customize: empanadas, eggplant special, sweet potatoes, roasted spaghetti squash, cremini shrooms to name a few.

photos.caption: Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

Fv__JuaddM8y-dQH14iuKA.text: Wow!  What an experience for the family while visiting Pittsburgh .... Assada platter, chorizo app(recommend the spicy!), roasted potatoes, empanadas(beef and pork) and salad delivered  .  The kids cleaned up the beef empanadas.  We wish we got more.

photos.caption: Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Gaucho

cHBexU8burkuyZKxriPnAw.text: First off I probably venture to Gaucho's no less than 2 times a month if not more for lunch during the week, not because of the close proximity to work, but for the exquisite lunch food at a decent price. Gaucho Parilla opens up at 11:00am but you should wander over if you don't want to wait in line; preferably 5 minutes before 11. This leaves you ample time to browse over the "chalkboard" menu on the wall. A couple of suggestions: if you are overwhelmed by the menu.  Appetizers: I would suggest the (beef or chicken) Empanadas or Provolleta  Lunch: Haven't had a bad sandwich yet but my go-to is the Rosemary Braised Beef and the Carne.  Also, their wings are smoked and grilled with the sauce layered after cooking.   They offer 4 main sauces set in various places around the restaurant that you can grab and taste to your liking.  If you are looking for a quick bite or a sit down lunch with friends this is the place. A modern, yet rustic look, topped with friendly employees and reasonable prices leaves this as a go-to for me every time.

PS1R8kM7p_DFp1A6W6IG3Q.text: This was one of the most amazing restaurant finds ever, and the food was nothing short of exceptional. I wanted to come here for every meal afterwards it was so tasty. It is an interesting ordering process where you wait in line and place your order first thing & then you are seated. The meat was so good & all the chimichurri sauces were mouth watering. We also tried the pork empanada of the day and some chorizo. This place was simply phenomenal. They don't have a liquor license, so you can bring your own bottle of wine and with no corkage fee either. Unbuckle your belt and dig in--it's delectable.

photos.caption: Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Empanadas Chorizos
Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Arrachera flank

FpwNVgavCY-shdMljJRXBg.text: Wow! It doesn't get much better than this. The steak platters were phenomenal (3 of us each tried the flank, filet and NY Strip) with small salad and piece of toast, however the chimichurri sauce on the steaks was a flavor bomb. Comes in two sizes 6oz and 12oz. The roasted carrots (with honey and feta) side dish is not to be missed, as was the spicy chorizo and empanadas. Do forget the superb flan for dessert. Incredibly inexpensive given the quality ($102 for 3). BYOB. Brought a bottle and they gladly opened and served in wine glasses with no corkage fee. I can see why there is a line out the door and down the block even on weekdays.   Have an unusual system. You queue in line (no reservations), winding past menu chalkboard. You approach cash register and pay, getting any drinks (including water). If you brought a bottle of wine you give it to them. After paying your bill, you wait at the cash register until they seat you at a table. When we got to the table, wine glasses were already present and wine opened. Food was served quickly as it was being prepared while waiting for a table. Service was excellent,  contemporary casual atmosphere. Wait was 30 min at 6pm on a Tuesday. Easy walk from Homewood Suites.  Highly recommended.

eXyVTeZgzYYicKTFntKbyQ.text: Overall a bad experience long wait times which is fine, but management and staff were incredibly rude. Will not be visiting again

OO9YPdRdGlk6W9C3k11Khw.text: How anyone can give this place anything besides 5 stars is beyond me. Hands down the best-tasting meat you will eat in the greater Pittsburgh area. The line can get VERY long during peak meal times, so be prepared to wait 30+ minutes before you even get in the door. There's absolutely no question that the food is worth the wait though, you will not regret waiting in line!

KHiYpy_3FZe2dNIyIaBZ3Q.text: This restaurant was one of the highlights of our trip! It's BYOB and there are no corkage/bottle fees. There was a line but we only waited about 30-40 minutes on a Friday and it was well worth it. We ordered the Asado Platter which includes 25 ounces of steak (5 different cuts), potatoes, and 3 pieces of toast. We didn't care for the toast but the potatoes cut so smoothly and melted in your mouth. The steak was really good- pair it with one of the four sauces they offer: incredible! We went in thinking we already knew which cuts we would like/dislike and it ended up being the opposite. The Asado Platter was $55.

photos.caption: Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Asado Plate
Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

rFlvWgSMBhozIYlb6R77ag.text: This is one of the best places I have been to in Pittsburgh!  Food: We spent only 75 dollars for 5 females. And it was really really delicious. The rib eye steak was juicy. It is a "must order dish". Qui Qui chicky was tender. Don't forget to squeeze some lemon juice on the meat! And the provoletta is also recommended. It tasted a little salty at first and then a milky taste would fill your mouth! We also had empanadas and steak burger. One of the empanada flavor was great, but I cannot remember it was beefy or vegi... :(. The steak burger was not as juicy as it was described in other comments, maybe it was because we were busy eating other food and did not eat the burger until it was cold.   Environment: It is small. Go there early! Better at 11! Otherwise, you will need to wait a long time.  Service: The waiters are prompt. There is no assigned waiter. So everyone passed by would help you if you need help!

photos.caption: Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

ZOVC_g68irL1lj0a91j8Og.text: Just got to town for a convention and absolutely starving so decided to look for yelp restaurant recommendations in close proximity to my hotel in downtown Pittsburgh. There was a jimmy johns and seven eleven across the street but after a harrowing 4 hour drive from DC I needed to reward myself with something amazing.   This restaurant was a little over half a mile from my hotel but I didn't care. Made the 6 block trek in record time and let's just say my stomach thanked me. I had the ribeye steak plate with a salad and the salad was a beautiful concoction of mixed greens with shaved carrots, baby tomatoes and radishes wonderfully dressed with a balsamic dressing and sprinkled with fresh black pepper. This place carries four house sauces. A chimnichurriesque one, a garlic, a Smokey one and one made of onions. All great accompaniments to the steak and salad. I actually drank some of the sauce from the little plastic cup because it was so good. I ordered the broccolini as an additional side and it came with a beautiful char off the grill. I drenched it in the garlic sauce and that just elevated the flavor although it was already divine. My favorite sauce was the garlic sauce but who doesn't love garlic but the others might appeal to others.   While the food was pretty awesome the wait staff were also very attentive. While you're ordering someone gets your table prepped and walks you to it. This same individual also brings you a sampler of the four sauces which I think is a nice touch.   This place only serves coke products but is byob with and no uncorking fee for those who need some wine with their steak. The table next to me appeared to be having a wine tasting party with their meal.

photos.caption: Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Tasting menu
Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Extensive meat menu
Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Delicious ribeye and broccolini linner

XStkwrHlY0d0klH5LPRNWg.text: No complaints at all. Very tasty, reasonable, and I look forward to going back!   Customer service was on point. The sauces for the dishes almost steal the show - almost. The meats were fantastic.

photos.caption: Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

d8EVqYgjHCzvEuZ5t71P4w.text: Had a wonderful experience at this restaurant for a private event. My friend was getting married and held the welcome reception or all her guests here. The basement has a trendy and cool vibe to it, with private alcoves cit wining comfy velour couches behind the main dining area. The meat was fantastically cooked and the sauces to die for. I would definitely come back here for the full dinning experience!

wk9-XdB3rI990Xfgjr7qMQ.text: Best food we've had in years - fantastic flank steak platter & the roasted squash & eggplant on point - the house sauces are amazing

Dv3uqiT7qtWpWQhHwiRN2A.text: I have eaten here several times since moving to Pittsburgh last summer, and it never fails to disappoint. Hands down my favorite go-to restaurant for bringing friends visiting from out of town, and also one I'll readily recommend to anyone asking for a new place to try. The concept is pretty simple, Argentinian style restaurant where pretty much everything is grilled. You can't go wrong with a classic steak plate--you choose the cut, they'll cook it to your preference, and it comes with chimichurri, salad, and grilled bread. The additional sides they offer are often changing, but always to die for. My favorite as of late are the roasted potatoes and garlic (those cloves are cooked to perfection and I could eat them all day, garlic breath included), and the honey glazed carrots with goat cheese. They also offer some fun traditional desserts. Thankfully most of their stuff is naturally gluten free, and I usually get a steak plate without the grilled bread. It may seem expensive at first glance, but I guarantee it is 100% worth it.

photos.caption: Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Steak with chimichurri
Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Steak plate, steak sandwich, sides, and dessert--more than enough of a lunch spread for 2 people
Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Poached pear flan

775nSyemLpPxgqM7U5aJBw.text: Wonderful sandwich shop in with he Strip District- long lines but worth the wait. They also have wonderful salads and other foods.  It is a very casual place with very friendly service and high quality flavorful food. Read the chalk board menu and be ready to order when you get to the register. They have nice seating inside and a funky patio outside but seats are limited.  We started with pork empanadas that required no sauces. The crust was perfect combination of crispy outside and flaky just underneath. The salads were fresh, large and tasty.  The star is the meat. We had sandwiches. The Carne is a pick your meat (filet, rib eye...) and how cooked (rare, medium rare...) on a nice bun with peppers and caramelized onions. They have a selection of tasty sauces to use as well.  Thoroughly enjoyed it.

photos.caption: Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Order counter
Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Menu board
Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Empanadas, sauces and house salad

3ZypTBUlcf2D2Z4rRdSJYA.text: WOWOWOWOWOWWWW. I LOVEEEE their menu selections! TBH, taste is like a 4.75, but their sauces, ambiance and service kick it up to 5!   Came at 11 AM and there was already a decent line wrapped around the building. Fear not though, they are speedy and efficient!  Basically, you choose your protein and can top it on a salad (small or large), sandwich or just on a platter. There are obviously lots of other protein options too....but I LOVE MY COW.   Everything was well prepared- I definitely don't have enough experience with the menu yet to advice people of what to get, but if you ever have questions about what you should get, ask the cashier! He is hella nice.   Parking: busy area! Almost like a Chinatown/Farmers Market area on weekends. Street it!   Overall, a must try if you are in PA! A pretty solid spot for brunch and dinner. Come early before they run out!

photos.caption: Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

jg1VZlOwo0Mxbq2-I89Z-A.text: I've gotta keep this succinct solely so whoever is reading this see's this review, reads it, and go's right to Gaucho to hop in line. Simply put, the food is incredible and ardently cooked and created.   The first two or three times I went, I wasn't a vegetarian and I had my pickings with the chicken and steak. Both indubitably incredible. The potatoes on the side are a must.   I've been back, ironically, as a vegetarian and still, the food is just as good. I've gotten a few salads, without the meat. And I still have no complaints. The vegetables and produce are fresh, and everything is tossed beautifully with tasteful dressing. I feel like I'm eating a 5 star meal without the 5 star price. It's pragmatically priced and seriously good.

OiMkJ1mbXrEeP6WDHXV4Ng.text: Came during the week for a late lunch (around 1pm?) and the long was only a few people with lots of table seating. You order when you get in and then there's a host who will find a table for you.   I wasn't that hungry so got the Provoletta. Like an open faced grilled cheese the provolone was melted over a slice of wood oven toast. Perfect vehicle for the sauces they provide. Nom nom. The provolone came with a small side salad.  The other dishes are sized for one hungry person or two light lunches. Sadly I didn't get to try anyone elses dishes are they were all gobbled up.

photos.caption: Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

ybu1nB3Uw6YYToUmlMq7kA.text: This was one of the most perfect meals I've ever eaten.  The menu is simple enough but well thought out.   The prices are exceptionally reasonable.  Were this a full service restaurant you'd pay at least twice the amount for the same food. The meats were flavorful, juicy and cooked perfectly.  The charred toast was the perfect accompaniment.  We also got the cheese and fruit board which was stellar.   I honestly can't remember a more perfect meal.

photos.caption: Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Board full of juicy steak.
Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. The end crispy bit is the best bite.
Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. The perfect bite.

oF2yjOKp0W0USD81HNDQHw.text: Where has this place been all my life? This was my first visit. If you like good steak, come here.  If you like good food, come here. Their menu is written on this huge chalkboard on the wall when you walk in.  My eyes gravitated towards their 5 steak cuts (flank, sirloin, skirt, ribeye, NY strip), so I can't comment on the other menu choices (yet!!!).    So once me and my dinner date got to the register, we ended up getting the Asado platter ($50) which contains all 5 cuts of heaven-- I mean steak. They say that's roughly 25oz of steak!  It also comes with three pieces of toast and chimichurri already on top.    Service was so fast!  And I was so fortunate to have come when there was no line (we got there around 6:15ish on a Tuesday)  We were seated very promptly, and served our food in a reasonable time too. I forgot to say that the ambiance isn't so quiet, so it's hard to have a good conversation in my opinion.  The only thing I wish is that it had salad on the side like the individualized steak platters have.  I needed some greens after downing more than 10oz of steak.. oh and UGHHH the sauces. Sososo yummy, just get all 4 and try them for yourselves.  I wanted to cry after eating my first piece. Ahhh... just thinking about it now I want to go back.  On the platter, they usually seem to organize the cuts in a certain order of sirloin, NY, skirt, ribeye, and flank.  In my opinion, the most expensive cut, the skirt, was my least favorite. My most favorite has to be the sirloin or flank, as they were the most tender.  Gaucho lives up to the hype.  Stop reading my review and just go eat there already!

photos.caption: Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Asado Platter (sirloin, NY, skirt, ribeye, flank)

YOoTCaFDUCgsUaH2rkqgfg.text: I'm newish to the area and have driven by a few times, it's hard to miss the line wrapped around the building so I figured I needed to see what the fuss was all about.  First, this place smells amazing.  Seriously, waiting in line isn't even bad because you just get to take in all the free smells.  It will make you more hungry than when you arrived though!   Second, the man that took my order was great!  I believe his name was Patrick.  Extremely knowledgeable and professional while maintaining efficiency with the line and keeping his cool.  I'm a district manager, so I know and appreciate good service when I see it.  I'd love to have this guy on my team.  12/10 would recommend.

YCpfRC4n8o8cwcqL-dQKbw.text: Cute location. Restaurant was clean and spacious . I ordered steak and empanadas. The steak was cooked well. Very tasty and nice side of salad that came with it! I've tasted better empanadas, but no serious complaints.

ozZiqw7dvb8djFD-Q980wg.text: I love it here. I mean, what's not to love? (Except for the wait). I could eat here everyday. The chicken sandwich is my favorite, and the side dishes are also incredible. I always eat my meal way too quickly so I don't have any pictures unfortunately.. you'll just have to take my word along with all of the hundreds of other yelp reviews.

6YXE53Nvpha8JctMC9bZrQ.text: The aroma that emerges from the restaurant is so tantalizing that i would stop by for a second meal. I've been to Gaucho several times, and by far I'd say the best part of their meals is the sauces. However, they can seem a bit heavy, so use with discretion! Food can be seasoned better. I feel that it is a hit or miss or perhaps all the seasoning went on one end of the meat, and I didn't get any of it...but when I do it tastes terrific. Lastly, I've consistently been getting overcooked steak, but thankfully their sauces make it much better.

vSrGoighRU0nirx9Z9h3SA.text: I got lucky because when I arrived there was no line.  That is unusual!  This place is popular.   Since I am not from the area and only travel here for work I haven't tried this place before.  I am so glad I did!  Wow!!!  The carne (steak) sandwich was a tender cut of meat on a great piece of bread with sauteed red peppers and onions.  Delish!   Add one (or more) of their 4 home made sauces and even more delish!  I also had a chicken and a beef empanada.  They were also fantastic.   I will be back!

photos.caption: Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Steak sandwich

LDvxwjF0D7D-BUXUZEgI5g.text: Fantastic and authentic Argentinian food with a unique and urban atmosphere. Hands down one of my favorite places in the city.

bI5p638vQELdYGXieZHEVQ.text: LOVE this place. The steak is excellent, and everything is good and reasonably priced. BYOB is nice too. Don't skip dessert, the bread pudding is phenomenal! The only down side is the wait can get long at certain times. Go a little early or late if you can, but if you do have to wait - it's worth it.

o6Np5RhPOr6S4bvZAc3Qtg.text: You want to know what I really appreciate about this meat-centric restaurant?  The sauces!!!   I have been to other churrascaria-style or meat oriented restaurants here and in other parts of the US ( I'm not going to mention names...One local one starts with G) and to ingest a plate full of potential heart attack substances without additional flavoring is ridiculous.  I know that some of you purists are going to say that the quality of the meat should speak for itself, but I don't agree. Just like I like my coffee with a flavored creamer, I want my meat with a lil sumthin, sumthin on the side. (Much like a an adulterer , but I digress...) This place has not one, not two, not three, but FOUR different sauces that you mix and match and slather/dip/gently brush/bathe your freshly grilled meats in.  I love that!  I have been hearing about this restaurant for a while, but it kind of dropped off of my radar for more than a minute.  (So many restaurants, so little money) but now that I'm back to my weekly habit of visiting the Strip District, I decided to stop in.  I noticed that the menu wasn't expansive, but I still had a problem deciding what I wanted to eat...Del Mar (Of the Sea) or De La Tierra (Gaucho's interpretation - Not of the Sea!)  Hmmm, meat platter, seafood platter, sammich, what to do?    After much time and deliberation, I decided to go with the Rosemary Braised Beef sandwich, Maiz (Grilled Corn on the Cobb) and two steak empanadas.  I also scarfed up samples of each of the sauces.    Call me Vampire Killer because I love garlic and that Ajo (garlic) sauce is drinkable in my opinion.  The chimichurri sauce and the cebolla (onion) sauce were also excellent.  The Rosemary Braised Beef was smoky, flavorful, tender and well balanced with the addition of caramelized onions and horseradish sauce. (Yeah, I know another sauce...but it was good!)  All corn should be grilled and seasoned the way Gaucho does it.  The only downer that I had was the steak empanada.  I bought two, one for myself and one for my daughter Muff and they were a little dry and overwhelmed by the taste of olives.  I love olives, but the olive taste wasn't balanced out by other flavors, so it was just bien. (okay).  After I raved about the restaurant to my sister, I had to take her there this past Saturday.  Not only did I reorder the same sandwich and grilled corn, I tasted some of my sister's Gaucho Papas (Seasoned Roasted Potatoes) Ay, Papi were they good!    Service at Gaucho's was extremely friendly and welcoming, with the staff more than willing to explain everything about their menu in detail.  The place is minutely small and you have to go outside to change your mind.  (The size of the place and empanadas is my only reason for a 4 rating)  All in all though, a very wonderful experience and you can't go wrong with the food there.  Besos (kisses) to the chefs and owners!

Xp9QcdDYS8oZm5io5cioxg.text: Very solid food for a good price.  The sauces are delicious and the meats have great flavor. If I was to complain about anything the sandwiches were almost made with too big slices of bread. Again, a small complaint. It is byob so don't expect to buy drinks here. I will definitely be returning

oRO0uRVkFHMsAIYwJUrsUA.text: If you are a True meat lover, look no further in Pittsburgh. Make sure to arrive 30-35 minutes prior to closing time so as to make sure you will be able to be seated.

B-84IBrtEk6n92T33EEsMA.text: Came here specifically for the paella after the place had been recommended to me multiple times from multiple people. Not sure if it's because of the high praise or if they were having an off day but I was sincerely let down. I felt pretty uncomfortable from the getgo - as if I was judged to be not /hip/ enough to be eating there. While ordering I asked for no chorizo on the paella and was asked if I wanted to substitute it for either tilapia or salmon. Neither sounded particularly appetizing so I opted for neither. The dude handling the order gave me a raised eyebrow look but proceeded in taking the order. While walking away to our table I turned back and overheard one of the cooks talking to the guy to reconfirm our order and seemed rather frustrated by my request. The place itself was rather hot and the music pretty loud (music selection however was ). Other than that - everything was otherwise clean, aesthetically pleasing, and the wait staff refilled our waters appropriately.   The paella itself was pretty lacking. There was no rice crust on the bottom, which felt sacrilegious. The shrimp on top were fresh and good quality but didn't have much flavor, nor did the rice. I know I asked for no chorizo but I didn't realize that they were incapable of imparting any flavor without it. Such a let down.   It being my first time there and not wanting to waste food, I asked one of the wait staff for a box and he pointed to the front room and said boxes were available in that vicinity - tbh I didn't really hear exactly where the boxes were because he turned his head to that direction while speaking and I felt too uncomfortable to ask him to repeat himself. My date ventured off to find the boxes and was only able to find tiny boxes - definitely not big enough to fill with absurd amount of rice we now had for the week. As a side note - the paella is noted to be big enough for 4-6 people, I knew this while ordering and it does not negatively impact my feelings on the food/restaurant itself. Luckily another wait staff member saw our tiny box dilemma and brought us two normal sized boxes which I was grateful for. He was also the only member who seemed genuinely courteous and professional as I watched him interact with other patrons. Also not really part of the review since it's not that kind of restaurant but I figured I'd mention it.   Overall, I was left unimpressed and probably won't return. Other people's food looked pretty good but I can only comment on my experience. If anyone reading is feeling daring and wants to try the paella for themselves I would recommend bringing some adobo along.

NEcUBVhHylukoP2DunAoYw.text: Despite being a non-beef eater, Gaucho has been on my radar for ages, and I finally made it in tonight.  Ironically, I wasn't planning to come here--I was actually planning to go to a Mexican place in Lawrenceville.  However, a bike path closure forced me to detour onto Smallman St., and I soon found myself in the heart of the Strip District at the corner of 21st.  A quick glance at my nearby bookmarked restaurants at 6:30pm indicated that most of them were closed, but that Gaucho was open for another half hour.  I realized this was my golden opportunity to try it, so after riding down a sketchy alleyway and parking my bike, in I walked.  If this wasn't serendipity, I don't know what is.  As I suspected, it wasn't busy, given how close it was to closing time.  Upon being greeted by a guy by the register, I mentioned that this was my first time visiting, and he explained that there isn't table service, but that I could order off the chalkboard menu.  I mentioned that I knew they were known for their steak sandwich, but that I didn't eat beef, and he explained how the turkey and chicken sandwiches differed.  Based on his description, I decided to try the chicken (pollo) sandwich with some grilled corn on the cob (maiz).  He mentioned that they were out of caramelized onions, but that he could put something else on instead, such as asparagus.  I love asparagus, so I told him that sounded like a great idea.  My order took about 10 min. to come up.   As I was waiting, I overheard the guy who'd waited on me speak to some customers seated at the counter.  He told them how he started working there and became the manager, and how some of the menu offerings were developed.  He also mentioned that he liked everything on the menu.  It was clear that he has a great sense of pride in the business!  When my order came up, I took it outdoors to the small patio adjoining the restaurant to eat, after getting some water, utensils, and all of the sauces.  After taking the obligatory photos, I tucked in.  It was delicious!  The meat on the sandwich was so tender, it melted in my mouth, and the asparagus and mushrooms were perfectly grilled.  The bread was fresh, chewy, and substantial.  Although the sandwich came with some ajo (garlic) sauce on it, I added some more, as well as some of the red pepper sauce and the cebolla (onion) sauce.  The corn made for a great accompaniment to the sandwich, esp. with all of the sauces drizzled on it.  The employees were even kind enough to give me two ears instead of the normal one, either because they were small or due to it being near the end of serving hours.  Aside from making occasional small noises (mmm, etc.), I'm pretty sure I didn't come up for air when eating.  Given that they were deep in conversation for most of the time I was eating, I don't know if the couple seated on the patio noticed me, but if they did, they probably nicknamed me something like "Hungry" due to my rabid and shifty-eyed devouring of the food.  Indeed, that food was so good, I'm glad I came alone so I didn't have to be embarrassed about my ravenousness or making a mess with the sauces!  You know the food's great when you don't want any distractions!

photos.caption: Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pollo (chicken) sandwich, cross section
Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pollo (chicken) sandwich, as served
Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Maiz (corn on the cob) w/ sauces

W41KfGCSir0OI_foFB0Ceg.text: Honestly don't understand why this place is so popular. Service is great but food is not edible. I went there twice and almost everything was burnt both times... If you are gonna burn everything and then call it authentic Argentinian grill, I don't have to pay for the price and could just do it at home

U3H-Y1WiaL8wmb_fc8mJeg.text: Superb.  Just not much to say, except be prepared to wait in line  for a bit.  But seriously worth it.

photos.caption: Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

nnQNXJmkUgf61S2d280llw.text: It was good as always. We had rosemary braised beef, steak burgh and maiz. love all 4 kind of sauce. the rosemary beef has been a all time favorite so far and we tried the steak sampler as well as some other sandwiches and burgh that i forgot about the name of. but everything we have tried here were great so i don't think anybody can ever go wrong with any pick.

vsdGtJ28Yp4QKVDZ97VSSg.text: Gaucho is always packed! The food is delicious given everything is firewood charred. You wait in line to order before sitting, so it's a great place to go with friends. I ordered papas al horno (oven roasted red potatoes with whole garlic cloves and fresh rosemary) as a side, and it does not disappoint. It's extremely flavorful and goes well with the free side dips as well. I also ordered camarones to share (cast iron seared shrimp with rosemary, garlic and lemon), which the searing of the garlic and lemon really brings out the flavor. The bondiola sandwich (roasted pulled pork, spicy mustard & caramelized onions) was also good, but the flavor is lighter in comparison to the  I other dishes. My personal favorite was the cordero (wood-fired New Zealand lamb chops done with grilled lemon, toast and fresh tossed salad). The lamb chops were well charred and the added berries as topping to the lamb was perfect.

photos.caption: Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Left: papas al horno ($3). Top: small camarones ($10). Right: half cordero ($16). Delicious!
Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Half cordero: wood-fired New Zealand lamb chops done with grilled lemon, toast and fresh tossed salad. ($16)
Photo of Gaucho Parrilla Argentina - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Bondiola sandwich: roasted pulled pork, spicy mustard &amp; caramelized onions. ($10)

IboMvOjd8Oqxppc2a5DzvQ.text: Very few words are needed. Long lines, get there early. Amazing food, Hard to pick.. Awesome sauces, Give them all a try. Small salad was a perfect size for lunch. Lots of veggie choices too!

m7Y_OP05C3LBIHrRGMFxuA.text: As a non-real-meat eater, I didn't think there would be anything for me here. But, I eat fish, and they have fish, and it is AMAZING! The shrimp was really really good and the BF enjoyed some pork and steak.   And the owner is pretty cool.

saywkN2cUDgce_U3fQydFA.text: I was in heaven as soon as I walked in and looked at that board. My only regret is that I had never been here before.  A friend and I walked in a little past 2pm on a Tuesday, and it wasn't over-crowded, but we had to wait for a group to leave to get a seat. No problem, though.   We ordered the meat plate to share including chorizo, chicken, and steak. This was easily the best chicken I have ever had. All of the meat was delicious, tender, and bursting with flavor. Seriously, melt-in-your-mouth good.  Watching the people working cut the giant hunks of meat is also entertaining. I love a place that sources their food responsibly (i.e. hormone/antibiotic free, presumably local) as possible, and they delivered.
